Spicy hot food has a chemical in it calledÂ 
capsaicin and when that hits your tongue itÂ Â

triggers two types of sensory neurons ... theÂ 
thermoreceptors is the first one and that sendsÂ Â

a message to your brain saying it's warm andÂ 
the nociceptors they're the ones that detectÂ Â

pain and in this case they incorrectly tell theÂ 
brain that this is burning hot. ğŸ”¥ The chilli isÂ Â

actually not hot and it's not burning the tongueÂ 
at all but your brain perceives it that way. ThisÂ Â

lady who can't feel pain ate a Carolina Reaper onÂ 
This Morning's show and describe the sensation as:Â Â

"It's warm i have a nice warm a nice glowingÂ 
warm feeling in my mouth". That shows us herÂ Â

thermoreceptors were still triggered but she hasÂ 
no nociceptors or pain receptors so she didn'tÂ Â

get that burning sensation. Now most of us doÂ 
feel pain ... it feels like burning on my tongueÂ Â

which i know it's not actually burning butÂ 
that doesn't help. But why do some of us feelÂ Â

the heat from chilli more than others? If youÂ 
eat hot chilli often the specific nociceptorsÂ Â

that are affected by capsaicin decreaseÂ 
in functionality over time so they sendÂ Â

less signals to your brain. Moving on to this oneÂ 
now that said it had the 'hit of chilli' ... thisÂ Â

was a hint this is a hit wow let's go!
There was no chilli in that one.Â

That one wasn't spicy at all.
They definitely taste orangeyÂ Â

it doesn't taste spicy.
I put that right back at one,Â Â

a hit is less than a hint apparently. In 1912Â 
Wilbur Scoville came up with a method to measureÂ Â

how hot different chillies were in comparison toÂ 
each other, with pure capsaicin up the top at 16Â Â

million scovilles, a jalapeno comes in at aroundÂ 
6 000, habanero about 200 000, ghost peppers wellÂ Â

they're around nine hundred thousand and carolinaÂ 
reaper roughly two million scovilles. The scaleÂ Â

tells you the number of times an extract from theÂ 
dried chilli was diluted in sweetened water beforeÂ Â

a panel of people could no longer detect anyÂ 
heat. Today the American spice trade associationÂ Â

pungency test is used and that measures theÂ 
actual amount of capsaicin in the food. It can beÂ Â

multiplied by 16 to get a rough equivalent numberÂ 
of scovilles. Next we have Hellraiser Milk ChilliÂ Â

chocolate milk chocolate with ghost chilliÂ 
cinnamon essential oil of sweet orange and cloveÂ Â

specialist chili products heat that comes for youÂ

And now on to the world's hottest chocolate barÂ 
which says it has nine million scoville chilliÂ Â

extract in it ğŸ’¥ On the back it says thisÂ 
12 piece chocolate bar is extremely spicyÂ Â

and is not to be consumed by those sensitiveÂ 
to spicy foods ... this product contains a highÂ Â

amount of pure chilli extract and is to be handledÂ 
with extreme caution. Consume at your own riskÂ Â

you can extract the capsaicinoids from lots ofÂ 
chilies and then concentrate that down until youÂ Â

have a paste. The Nile Red channel explains thatÂ 
process in detail so you can watch that there butÂ Â

essentially you end up with a ridiculously hotÂ 
concentrate of capsaicin which even the tiniestÂ Â

bit on the end of a toothpick can cause pain.Â 
It doesn't say how much of this is in the barÂ Â

i feel like once you're using capsaicin extractÂ 
it needs to have stricter labelling regulationsÂ Â

so people know exactly how much is in it. TwoÂ 
British journalists tried an extreme burger whichÂ Â

had lots of capsaicin extract in the source theyÂ 
only had one bite each and both of them ended upÂ Â

in hospital one of them lost feeling in his handsÂ 
his legs were shaking and his eyes rolled backÂ Â

the other said he was in so much pain inÂ 
his stomach that he felt like he was dyingÂ Â

and while in most cases these side effectsÂ 
are temporary and they will pass with timeÂ Â

there are some rare cases that have beenÂ 
reported that have been more serious.Â Â

A healthy 15 year old who ate a carolinaÂ 
reaper got a severe disabling headacheÂ Â

and hospital tests showed that it was caused byÂ 
a sudden constriction of the blood vessels thatÂ Â

supply oxygen to the brain. A 47 year old guy ateÂ 
ghost peppers and went to hospital with severeÂ Â

abdominal pain and struggling to breathe and testsÂ 
showed he had a collapsed lung and he'd rupturedÂ Â

his oesophagus which can be deadly! He survivedÂ 
as well but he stayed in hospital for 23 daysÂ Â

before he could be discharged. So know your limitsÂ 
with spicy foods and it's always okay to say no.
